questions.text: Fetal growth is maximally affected by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Insulin Insulin plays a crucial role in fetal growth and is considered the hormone that maximally affects it. During fetal development, insulin is responsible for promoting growth by facilitating the uptake of glucose into fetal cells, which provides the energy needed for tissue formation and organ development. It also helps in the synthesis of proteins and fats, which are essential for the growing fetus. Fetal insulin levels rise throughout pregnancy, reflecting its key role in regulating growth. Explanation for the other options: B. Growth hormone Growth hormone is important for postnatal growth, but it has less impact on fetal growth compared to insulin. Growth hormone's main effects are on skeletal and tissue growth after birth, and it plays a minimal role in fetal development. C. Cortisol Cortisol, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands, influences fetal organ maturation (e.g., the lungs, liver) and prepares the fetus for life outside the womb. However, while cortisol helps in organ maturation, it is not the main hormone for promoting growth in the fetus, especially in terms of size and weight. D. Thyroxine Thyroxine, or thyroid hormone, is essential for the development of the nervous system and is critical for overall fetal development. However, its role in regulating growth is secondary to that of insulin. Thyroid hormone deficiency can impair development, but it is not as significant a driver of fetal growth as insulin

questions.text: Tripling of weight occurs at what age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 12 months Tripling of a baby's birth weight typically occurs by 12 months of age. This is a well-established milestone in infant growth and development. By the time a baby reaches 1 year, their weight has generally tripled compared to their birth weight. Explanation for other options: A. 5 months At 5 months, babies typically double their birth weight, not triple it. B. 6 months By 6 months, most infants have doubled their birth weight, but not tripled it. This is still before the time for tripling, which happens around 12 months. D. 24 months By 24 months (2 years), the weight gain is slower, and while a child will continue to grow, tripling the birth weight happens around 12 months, not 24 months.

questions.text: Half the adult height is attained at what age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2 years By the age of 2 years, most children have reached about half of their expected adult height. This growth milestone is a general guideline for pediatric growth and reflects the rapid growth that occurs in the first two years of life. Explanation for the other options: A. 1 year At 1 year, most children have not yet reached half of their adult height. Growth in the first year is significant, but not as much as by 2 years. C. 3 years By 3 years, a child is closer to half of their adult height, but this milestone typically occurs at 2 years, not 3. D. 4 years At 4 years, children may be slightly more than half of their expected adult height, but the key milestone of "half the adult height" is generally attained by 2 years.

questions.text: The percentage gain in height at end of first year of life is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 50% By the end of the first year of life, an infant's height typically increases by about 50% from their birth length. This rapid growth during the first year is part of the normal growth and development process. For example, if a baby is born at a length of 50 cm, by the end of the first year, their length would generally be around 75 cm, reflecting a 50% increase. Explanation for the other options: A. 25% A 25% increase in height would be too low for the first year of life, as growth during this period is more rapid. C. 75% A 75% increase in height by the end of the first year is too high, as the typical increase is about 50%. D. 100% A 100% increase in height would mean that the child has doubled their length, which is not typical in the first year.

questions.text: The recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for zinc in age group of 1 to 3 years is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 5 mg/day The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for zinc in children aged 1 to 3 years is 5 mg/day. Zinc is an essential mineral for growth, immune function, and wound healing, and meeting the RDA ensures that the child's needs are adequately met for these processes. Explanation for other options: A. 20 mg/day This is too high for children in the 1-3 years age group. It might be a dose used for supplementation in cases of deficiency, but it is not the RDA. B. 10 mg/day This is also above the recommended RDA for this age group. It's closer to the upper safe limit but is not the standard recommendation. C. 7.5 mg/day This is still higher than the RDA for this age group

questions.text: Delayed dentition is failure of teeth to erupt by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 13 months Delayed dentition refers to the delayed eruption of teeth in infants and children. According to pediatric guidelines, if a child has not started to erupt their first tooth by 13 months of age, it is considered a case of delayed dentition. Explanation for other options: A. 6 months While it is typical for the first tooth to emerge around 6 months, this is not considered delayed dentition. This is within the normal range for tooth eruption. B. 9 months By 9 months, many children have started to show some tooth eruption, so this would not be classified as delayed. C. 12 months Many children begin to show teeth by 12 months, but a delay in eruption is generally only noted if no teeth appear by 13 months.

questions.text: Long, mildly pigmented pubic hair with enlarged, pink scrotum is seen in which SMR stage in boys?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SMR 2 In the Tanner stages or Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR), SMR Stage 2 in boys is characterized by the beginning of pubertal development. The key features of SMR stage 2 include: Pubic hair: Fine, long, and lightly pigmented pubic hair begins to appear, typically around the base of the penis. Scrotum: The scrotum becomes enlarged and pink in color as the testes start to grow. At this stage, boys begin to show early signs of puberty, such as the appearance of pubic hair and changes in the external genitalia. Explanation for the other options: A. SMR 1 Stage 1 represents pre-pubertal development, where there is no pubic hair, and the scrotum and penis are not enlarged. C. SMR 3 In SMR 3, the pubic hair becomes coarser and darker, and the scrotum is further enlarged. This stage involves more significant development compared to SMR 2. D. SMR 4 Stage 4 shows more advanced changes with the development of adult-like pubic hair and a fully enlarged and darker scrotum, marking a later stage in puberty.

questions.text: First sign of puberty in females?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The first sign of puberty in females is thelarche, which refers to the onset of breast development. It typically occurs around the age of 8 to 13 years and marks the beginning of sexual maturation in girls. Thelarche results from increased estrogen secretion and is classified as Tanner stage 2 in pubertal development. A. Growth spurt – Incorrect. Although a growth spurt occurs early in puberty, it generally follows thelarche. It is not the first sign, but rather one of the early signs that occur after breast budding. B. Menarche – Incorrect. Menarche, or the first menstrual period, occurs later in puberty, typically 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche. It is considered a late event in the sequence of female pubertal development. C. Pubarche – Incorrect. Pubarche is the appearance of pubic hair, which occurs due to adrenal androgen production. It often occurs after or around the same time as thelarche but is not typically the first sign.

questions.text: First visible sign of puberty in females?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Thelarche The first visible sign of puberty in females is thelarche, which refers to the development of breast buds or the initial growth of breast tissue. This is typically the earliest physical change that is noticeable to both the individual and others. Thelarche usually occurs around ages 8 to 13 and is a key milestone in the process of puberty. The sequence of puberty in females often follows this pattern: Thelarche – The development of breast buds. Growth spurt – Rapid increase in height, which follows thelarche. Pubarche – The appearance of pubic hair. Menarche – The onset of menstruation, which is one of the final signs of puberty. Explanation for other options: A. Growth spurt The growth spurt is an important change, but it is usually not the first visible sign. It follows after thelarche in most females. B. Menarche Menarche is the first menstrual period, which happens later in puberty and after the appearance of breast development and other changes. C. Pubarche Pubarche refers to the development of pubic hair and typically occurs after thelarche. It is a significant sign but comes after the initial visible breast development.

questions.text: Microcephaly is defined as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) HC below -3 SD Microcephaly is defined as a condition where the head circumference (HC) is more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for age and sex. This corresponds to HC below -3 SD from the expected normal head size, indicating a significantly smaller than average head size for a given age and sex. A. HC below 34 cm: This is not a specific measurement for microcephaly, as head circumference varies based on age and sex. B. HC below -2 SD: A head circumference below -2 SD may indicate a smaller head size but does not meet the criteria for microcephaly. This is a threshold for "below average" but not severe enough to be classified as microcephaly. D. HC below 10th centile: While this indicates a smaller head size compared to the population, microcephaly is typically defined as more than -3 SD, which is more stringent than just being below the 10th centile.

questions.text: The important fatty acid present in breast milk, important for growth is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) is a crucial omega-3 fatty acid found in breast milk and is essential for growth, particularly for the development of the brain and eyes. DHA is vital in the early stages of life as it plays a key role in the development of the central nervous system, including cognitive and visual function. Incorrect Options: B. Palmitic acid: While palmitic acid is the most common saturated fatty acid found in breast milk, it is not as crucial for growth and development as DHA. C. Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is an essential omega-6 fatty acid, but it is not as directly related to growth and brain development as DHA. D. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is another essential fatty acid, specifically omega-3, but DHA is the more important fatty acid in terms of brain development and growth in infants.

questions.text: Most common cause of short stature is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Constitutional Constitutional short stature is the most common cause of short stature in children. It refers to a variation of normal growth, where the child is simply growing at a slower rate but will eventually reach a normal adult height based on their genetic potential. This condition is not associated with any underlying disease or disorder and is often seen in children with a family history of short stature or delayed growth. Incorrect Options: B. Hypothyroidism: While hypothyroidism can cause growth failure, it is less common compared to constitutional short stature. If present, hypothyroidism typically presents with other signs and symptoms like lethargy, weight gain, and dry skin. C. Growth hormone deficiency: Growth hormone deficiency can also cause short stature, but it is less common than constitutional short stature. It can present with a lack of growth velocity, and if untreated, it may lead to dwarfism. D. Systemic illness: Various systemic illnesses can lead to growth failure, but these are less common causes of short stature compared to constitutional factors. Systemic illnesses may affect growth by impairing nutrition, metabolism, or overall health.

choices.text: Neonates with constitutional delay show birth anomalies
IGF-1 levels are low for chronological age
IGF-1 levels are low for bone age

questions.text: Which among the following is true about constitutional delay in growth?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IGF-1 levels are low for chronological age. Constitutional delay in growth is a common variation in normal development where children experience a delay in growth and puberty but eventually catch up to their peers. One of the key features of this condition is that IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor 1) levels are low for chronological age. IGF-1 plays a crucial role in growth and is typically lower in children with constitutional delay, as their growth hormone axis is temporarily less active. However, once they enter puberty, their growth typically accelerates, and IGF-1 levels increase. Incorrect responses: A. Neonates with constitutional delay show birth anomalies: Children with constitutional delay in growth generally do not have birth anomalies. They tend to have a normal prenatal and birth history but exhibit slower growth postnatally. Birth anomalies are not characteristic of this condition. C. Bone age is normal: In constitutional delay, bone age is typically delayed compared to the chronological age. Bone age is used as an indicator of physical development, and in constitutional delay, it tends to lag behind chronological age, rather than being normal. D. IGF-1 levels are low for bone age: In constitutional delay, IGF-1 levels are low for chronological age, not for bone age. The delay in bone age correlates with the delay in growth, but IGF-1 levels are generally lower when compared to what would be expected for the child's chronological age.

questions.text: Artificial feeding causes all of the following except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hemorrhagic disease. Artificial feeding (or formula feeding) can be associated with several health concerns, but hemorrhagic disease is not one of them. Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is typically caused by a deficiency of vitamin K, which can lead to bleeding and bruising. This condition is unrelated to the method of feeding, as it is primarily related to the baby’s inability to synthesize vitamin K in the early weeks of life. Vitamin K deficiency is usually prevented with a vitamin K injection shortly after birth, regardless of whether the baby is breastfed or artificially fed. Incorrect responses: A. NEC (Necrotizing Enterocolitis): Necrotizing enterocolitis is a serious gastrointestinal issue that can occur in premature or low birth weight infants, particularly those who are artificially fed. The risk of NEC is higher in infants who are formula-fed compared to those who are breastfed, due to the differences in the immune protection and gut flora provided by breast milk. B. Eczema: Eczema (or atopic dermatitis) is a common skin condition that has been associated with artificial feeding. Formula feeding can influence the development of allergic conditions, including eczema, especially if the baby has a genetic predisposition to allergies. C. Late onset tetany: Late-onset tetany can occur due to a calcium imbalance, which may be influenced by artificial feeding if the formula does not provide adequate levels of calcium and other nutrients. This condition is more likely to develop in artificially fed infants who do not receive optimal nutrition.

choices.text: Start calorie and fat rich diet

questions.text: A 6 year old child is brought to OPD with complaints that “the child doesn’t eat much and is weak”. On anthropometric assessment, weight of the child is found to be 18 kg and height of the child is 110 cm. What shall be your advice to the parents?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Continue normal feeding as before. Based on the information provided, the child’s weight is 18 kg and height is 110 cm. When assessing growth, it is important to compare these measurements to age and sex-specific growth charts. For a 6-year-old child, these values generally fall within the normal range (the child's weight and height correspond to approximate percentiles in most growth charts). The complaint of not eating much and being weak might indicate temporary issues, but the child’s growth measurements do not suggest significant malnutrition or abnormal growth. Therefore, the appropriate advice would be to continue normal feeding unless other signs or clinical indicators suggest a more serious problem. Incorrect responses: A. Start multivitamins with iron: While iron deficiency or other vitamin deficiencies can cause weakness or poor appetite, there is no clear evidence of deficiency from the provided information. Without additional signs of nutritional deficiencies (such as pallor or developmental delays), it is not necessary to start multivitamins with iron at this stage. B. Start calorie and fat-rich diet: The child’s weight and height appear within normal limits for their age, so there is no indication that they need a calorie- and fat-rich diet. Encouraging a balanced diet is important, but drastic changes in diet are unnecessary unless a clinical assessment indicates undernutrition. C. Start protein-rich diet: The child’s growth parameters do not suggest protein malnutrition. A protein-rich diet is typically recommended if there are signs of protein deficiency, but in this case, the child’s growth is not significantly abnormal to justify a protein-focused intervention.

choices.text: Rate of increase of height and weight

questions.text: Best indicator for nutritional status for a child is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rate of increase of height and weight The best indicator for nutritional status for a child is the rate of increase of height and weight (Option C). This is because tracking the growth pattern through changes in weight and height provides the most direct and comprehensive measure of a child’s nutritional health. These two parameters reflect the child’s overall growth trajectory and help to identify nutritional deficiencies or excesses. Regular monitoring of growth ensures early identification of growth faltering, stunted growth, or undernutrition, making it a reliable method for assessing the child’s overall nutritional status. Incorrect Options: Option A: Mid arm circumference - While mid-arm circumference can be an indicator of malnutrition, particularly in children with severe undernutrition, it does not provide a full picture of nutritional status. It primarily reflects muscle mass rather than overall growth, and may miss other aspects of nutritional health such as protein-energy malnutrition. Option B: Head circumference - Head circumference is a useful measure in infants, particularly for assessing brain growth. However, it is not a comprehensive indicator of general nutritional status. While severe malnutrition can affect brain growth, changes in head circumference do not directly reflect the child’s overall nutritional intake or growth. Option D: Chest circumference - Chest circumference is typically used to assess lung and respiratory development, particularly in newborns. It does not offer a clear or complete assessment of a child’s nutritional status. Unlike height and weight, chest circumference is not sensitive to changes in nutrition or overall growth.

questions.text: Marker for both acute and chronic malnutrition is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Weight for age. Weight for age is an important marker for assessing both acute and chronic malnutrition. This indicator compares a child's weight to the average weight expected for their age, providing a clear view of their overall nutritional status. A deviation from the norm can indicate undernutrition caused by both recent inadequate nutrition (acute malnutrition) and long-term nutritional deficiencies (chronic malnutrition). Thus, weight for age reflects both the immediate and long-standing impacts of poor nutrition. Incorrect Options: Option A: Weight for height - Weight for height is primarily used to assess acute malnutrition, particularly wasting. It compares a child’s weight to the average weight expected for their height and is sensitive to recent changes in nutritional status. However, it does not provide a comprehensive measure of long-term nutritional history or chronic malnutrition. Option B: BMI - Body Mass Index (BMI) is not the best marker for nutritional status in children, especially in younger age groups. Although it assesses weight in relation to height, it is less sensitive to variations in nutrition, and its application for children can be less accurate due to growth patterns. BMI is more commonly used in adults to assess underweight and obesity, but it is not an ideal measure for malnutrition in children. Option D: Height for age - Height for age is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, particularly stunting. It compares a child’s height with the expected height for their age, and it reflects long-term nutritional deficiencies affecting growth. However, it does not assess recent changes in weight or more immediate malnutrition, so it’s not a complete indicator for both acute and chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are observed in marasmus except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hepatomegaly. Explanation: Marasmus is a severe form of malnutrition caused by a deficiency of calories and proteins, often seen in children. It leads to muscle wasting, extreme weakness, and low insulin levels. Hepatomegaly, or enlargement of the liver, is not a typical feature of marasmus. Instead, this condition is more commonly associated with another type of malnutrition known as kwashiorkor, which involves protein deficiency and can cause liver enlargement due to the accumulation of fat in the liver. Incorrect responses: B. Muscle wasting: Muscle wasting is a hallmark of marasmus. The body begins to break down its own muscle tissue to provide energy in the absence of sufficient nutritional intake, leading to progressive loss of muscle mass. C. Low insulin levels: Insulin levels tend to be low in marasmus due to the body's depleted energy stores and inadequate intake of nutrients. This response is due to the body's attempt to conserve energy by limiting anabolic processes like protein synthesis. D. Extreme weakness: Extreme weakness is also a common feature of marasmus. The lack of calories and proteins impairs the body's ability to generate energy, leading to severe fatigue and weakness due to muscle wasting and insufficient nutrition.

questions.text: All of the following are features of kwashiorkor except –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High blood osmolarity. Explanation: Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency of dietary protein, despite adequate caloric intake. The key features of kwashiorkor include hypoalbuminemia (low levels of albumin in the blood), edema (fluid retention, often leading to swelling), and fatty liver (due to the inability to transport lipids properly because of protein deficiency). However, high blood osmolarity is not a typical feature of kwashiorkor. In fact, due to the loss of proteins like albumin in the blood, osmolarity tends to be low, as the lack of protein reduces the osmotic pressure needed to retain fluid within the vascular system. This results in fluid leakage into tissues, causing edema. Incorrect responses: B. Hypoalbuminemia: Hypoalbuminemia is a hallmark of kwashiorkor. The lack of dietary protein leads to a deficiency in albumin, which is the primary protein in blood plasma responsible for maintaining oncotic pressure. This contributes to fluid leakage from blood vessels into the tissues, resulting in edema. C. Edema: Edema is a characteristic feature of kwashiorkor. Due to the low albumin levels in the blood, the osmotic pressure is insufficient to retain fluid within the blood vessels, leading to fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces, which manifests as swelling in the limbs, abdomen, and face. D. Fatty liver: Fatty liver occurs in kwashiorkor due to the liver's inability to properly synthesize lipoproteins needed to transport fats. As a result, triglycerides accumulate in the liver, causing it to become fatty.

questions.text: Diagnosis of kwashiorkor is based on?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Edema and mental changes. Kwashiorkor is a severe form of malnutrition that results from a protein deficiency despite adequate caloric intake. The diagnosis of kwashiorkor is primarily based on the presence of edema (swelling due to fluid retention) and mental changes (such as irritability, apathy, and developmental delays). These symptoms are characteristic of the condition, as the lack of protein, particularly albumin, leads to a decrease in oncotic pressure, causing fluid to leak from the blood vessels into tissues, resulting in edema. The mental changes arise from the lack of essential nutrients, including proteins and amino acids, which are necessary for brain function. Incorrect responses: A. Edema and skin changes: While edema is a hallmark of kwashiorkor, skin changes (such as depigmentation or dermatitis) are not the primary criteria for diagnosis. These skin changes can occur, but they are not as central to the diagnosis as edema and mental changes. C. Weight loss and mental changes: While mental changes are seen in kwashiorkor, weight loss is typically more associated with marasmus, another form of malnutrition where both caloric and protein intake are insufficient. Kwashiorkor often occurs despite adequate caloric intake, so significant weight loss is not the most prominent feature. D. Bitot spots and hepatomegaly: Bitot spots (keratinized areas on the conjunctiva) and hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) are more commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency or other nutritional deficiencies, but they are not specific to kwashiorkor.

questions.text: Age independent anthropometric indices include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gomez index. The Gomez index is age-dependent because it compares a child's weight-for-age against established age-specific standards. This index is useful in assessing malnutrition in children, but since it involves age-specific weight measurements, it is not considered an age-independent anthropometric index. Incorrect responses: A. Rao scale: The Rao scale is an age-independent anthropometric index. It is used to assess nutritional status based on a set of simple measurements, such as weight-for-height, which do not rely on age-specific reference standards. B. Jellife index: The Jellife index is another age-independent index. It evaluates nutritional status by considering the ratio of a person's weight-to-height measurements, which can be applied across different ages without needing age-specific reference data. D. Quac Stick: The Quac Stick (or Quacquarelli Scale) is an age-independent anthropometric index used for nutritional assessment. It compares the weight-for-height ratio, a method that doesn't rely on the individual's age, making it suitable for general nutritional assessment across all age groups.

questions.text: Cerebellar ataxia is feature of which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vit E (Vitamin E). Vitamin E deficiency is known to cause cerebellar ataxia, which is characterized by a lack of coordination and balance due to damage to the cerebellum, the part of the brain responsible for motor control. Vitamin E acts as a powerful antioxidant and is essential for the maintenance of the nervous system, including the cerebellum. Deficiency in this vitamin can lead to neurological symptoms like ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, and other motor dysfunctions. Incorrect responses: A. Vit A (Vitamin A): Vitamin A deficiency does not cause cerebellar ataxia. It is more commonly associated with visual disturbances, such as night blindness, and in severe cases, can lead to blindness. It also affects skin health and immune function but does not directly cause cerebellar ataxia. B. Vit C (Vitamin C): Vitamin C deficiency primarily leads to scurvy, which causes symptoms like bleeding gums, joint pain, and anemia. It does not cause cerebellar ataxia, which is more specific to vitamin E deficiency. D. Vit D (Vitamin D): Vitamin D deficiency primarily results in bone disorders like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. While it can cause muscle weakness, it is not typically associated with cerebellar ataxia.

questions.text: When can a child speak future tense?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 5 years. Children typically start to understand and use the future tense around the age of 5. At this age, they begin to grasp the concept of time and can use future tense forms in their speech. While earlier development includes understanding basic concepts of the present and past tenses, it is around age 5 that they can consistently use the future tense, such as saying "I will play" or "I am going to school." Incorrect responses: A. 2 years: At 2 years, children are typically just beginning to form simple sentences and use basic tenses like the present (e.g., "I eat" or "I play"). They are not yet using the future tense. B. 3 years: By age 3, children may start using more complex sentences and might begin to use simple future phrases like "I will," but the consistent use of the future tense is not typical at this stage. C. 4 years: At 4 years, children may begin to use the future tense occasionally, but it is still developing. The use of future tense becomes more consistent and accurate around 5 years of age.

questions.text: A child gets a vocabulary of 50 words at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 24 months. A child typically has a vocabulary of 50 words around 24 months (2 years old). At this stage, children's vocabulary rapidly expands, and they begin to use simple two-word combinations like "want cookie" or "big truck." By 24 months, most children reach this milestone as part of their language development. Incorrect responses: A. 12 months: At 12 months (1 year), most children have a vocabulary of around 1 to 3 words. Language development at this stage is just beginning, with children primarily focusing on understanding words before they start using them consistently. B. 15 months: At 15 months, a child may have a small vocabulary of around 5 to 10 words. While some children may start using more words, the vocabulary of 50 words is typically not reached until later. C. 18 months: By 18 months, a child may have around 20-30 words in their vocabulary, but they are still building their word bank. The milestone of 50 words is generally reached by 24 months.

choices.text: Absence of pincer grasp by 10 months
Inability to stand without support by 12 months
Lack of imaginative play by 2 years

questions.text: Which among the following is a red flag sign for abnormally delayed development in a child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absence of vocalization by 6 months. Absence of vocalization by 6 months is a red flag sign for abnormally delayed development in a child. By 6 months, most babies start making sounds and experimenting with their vocalizations, such as cooing, babbling, and making a variety of noises. The absence of vocalization at this stage could indicate a developmental delay, hearing problem, or other concerns related to speech and language development. Incorrect responses: B. Absence of pincer grasp by 10 months: While the pincer grasp (using the thumb and forefinger to pick up small objects) is usually developed by 9-10 months, its absence by 10 months is not necessarily a red flag. Some children may develop it a bit later, but it generally emerges by the end of the first year. C. Inability to stand without support by 12 months: Standing without support is a milestone that typically occurs around 12 months. However, some children may not be able to stand independently until closer to 14 or 15 months. A delay in this skill is not necessarily a red flag, as children develop motor skills at different rates. D. Lack of imaginative play by 2 years: Imaginative play usually starts emerging around 2 years and becomes more apparent by 3 years. While its absence at 2 years could be a concern in some cases, it is generally not considered a definitive red flag at this age, as some children develop this skill later.

questions.text: A child learns to draw a circle by what age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 36 months. Drawing a circle is a milestone that typically occurs around the age of 3 years (36 months). At this age, children begin to develop better fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination, allowing them to make more controlled and intentional drawings. A circle is one of the first shapes that children are able to draw as part of their early artistic development. Incorrect responses: A. 12 months: At 12 months, children are still in the early stages of developing motor skills. They may be able to make random scribbles or lines, but drawing a circle is not expected at this stage. B. 24 months: By 24 months, children may start to show some ability to scribble and create basic shapes, but they are typically not able to draw a recognizable circle. More complex shapes like circles are usually drawn closer to 3 years of age. C. 30 months: While some children may begin to attempt drawing circles around 30 months, it is generally expected that most children will consistently draw a circle by 36 months.

questions.text: A female child has recently learnt to eat with spoon without spilling, dress and undress under supervision and understand she is a girl. These skills are first acquired between the age of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 3 and 4 years. The skills described—eating with a spoon without spilling, dressing and undressing with supervision, and understanding her gender identity—are typical milestones acquired between the ages of 3 and 4 years. During this stage, children develop greater independence in self-help skills, including feeding themselves and participating in dressing activities. They also begin to have a better understanding of social concepts, such as gender identity. Incorrect responses: A. 2 and 3 years: At 2 to 3 years, children are still developing basic motor and self-help skills. While they may start attempting to feed themselves and undress with help, the level of coordination and understanding described in the question is typically not reached until 3 to 4 years. C. 4 and 5 years: By this age, children usually become more proficient in self-care skills, including dressing and undressing independently and eating without spilling. However, the skills mentioned in the question are typically acquired earlier, around 3 to 4 years, rather than 4 to 5 years. D. 5 and 6 years: At 5 to 6 years, children are generally well beyond the stage of learning basic self-help skills like eating with a spoon or dressing with supervision. By this age, children are typically expected to perform these tasks independently.

questions.text: A child can self-feed with spoon without spilling, copy a circle, dress and undress independently but cannot close and open his buttons. What is the likely age at which this development status is first attained?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 3 years. At around 3 years of age, children typically develop the ability to self-feed with a spoon without spilling, copy a circle, and dress and undress independently. By this age, they are becoming more skilled in fine motor tasks and can manage basic self-care activities with little help. However, closing and opening buttons is a more complex fine motor skill that usually develops closer to 4 years or later. It requires greater dexterity and hand-eye coordination, which is why it might not be fully mastered at 3 years. Incorrect responses: A. 2 years: By 2 years, children are just starting to develop some self-feeding and dressing skills, but they are generally not able to consistently use a spoon without spilling, copy shapes like a circle, or dress and undress independently. Buttoning and fine motor tasks like these are typically beyond the capability of most 2-year-olds. C. 4 years: By 4 years, children usually have mastered more advanced self-help skills, including buttoning and more refined fine motor tasks. However, the skills mentioned in the question—self-feeding with a spoon, copying a circle, and dressing independently—are typically attained a bit earlier, around 3 years. D. 5 years: At 5 years, children are generally proficient in a wide range of self-help skills, including more complex tasks like buttoning and zipping clothes. However, the skills mentioned in the question (such as self-feeding with a spoon and copying a circle) are typically developed by the age of 3, not 5.

questions.text: What is the expected age at which the following milestone is first attained?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6 months. The child is described as being 3 years old (36 months), which aligns with the milestones mentioned: the child learns to self-feed well (without spilling) between 15-18 months, can copy a circle at 3 years, and can self-dress and undress at 3 years. However, the child is not yet independent in dressing and undressing, which typically happens at 4 years. Based on the provided information, the child is at 3 years and 6 months (36 months + 6 months), making the correct age 3 years and 6 months, or B. 6 months. Incorrect responses: A. 4 months: 4 months is far too early for the described milestones. At 4 months, a child is just beginning to develop motor skills, and milestones like self-feeding, copying shapes, or dressing independently are not achievable at this age. C. 7 months: 7 months is also too early. At this age, children are just beginning to sit up and develop rudimentary hand-eye coordination. Milestones such as self-feeding with a spoon or dressing themselves are not expected at 7 months. D. 9 months: 9 months is still too early for these milestones. At this age, children may begin to explore their environment and reach for objects but are far from mastering self-feeding, copying shapes, or dressing themselves independently.

choices.text: Have a vocabulary of 50 to 100 words

questions.text: A 3 year old child can do all of the following except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tying of shoelaces comes at 4 to 5 years of age.

questions.text: A normal child has dysfluency of speech between?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2 to 4 years. It is completely normal for a child to experience dysfluency of speech (such as stuttering or repeating words) between the ages of 2 to 4 years. This is a phase that often occurs as children are learning to speak more fluently and are still developing their language and communication skills. During this time, children may have difficulty coordinating their speech and thoughts, leading to some interruptions in their speech patterns. This type of dysfluency is typically temporary and resolves as the child's language skills mature. Incorrect responses: B. 4 to 6 years: Although some children may continue to show signs of dysfluency beyond the age of 4, the majority of typical children will have outgrown the most significant speech disfluency by the age of 4. If dysfluency persists after this period, it may be a sign of a speech or language disorder that requires further evaluation. C. 6 to 8 years: By 6 to 8 years, most children have developed more consistent speech fluency. Persistent stuttering or other speech issues beyond this age may indicate a speech disorder, and it is not considered a normal developmental stage. D. 8 to 10 years: At 8 to 10 years, children are generally able to speak fluently without significant dysfluency. If dysfluency continues at this stage, it could be a sign of a more serious speech issue, and further evaluation would be needed.

questions.text: A 3 year old child is categorised as developmentally delayed if he is unable to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Use spoon effectively without spilling. At 3 years old, children are expected to be able to use a spoon effectively without spilling, which is a key milestone in developing fine motor skills and self-feeding abilities. If a 3-year-old is unable to perform this task, it could be a sign of developmental delay. This milestone is typically achieved between 2 to 3 years, so if the child cannot do it by 3, it might indicate a delay in their fine motor development. Incorrect responses: A. Copy a square: By 4 years, children are typically expected to be able to copy simple shapes like squares and circles. At 3 years, copying a square may be challenging but still within the typical developmental range. Therefore, being unable to copy a square at 3 does not necessarily indicate developmental delay. B. Hop on one foot: At 3 years, many children are able to hop on one foot, but some may still be developing their balance and coordination. This skill is often refined around 4 years. So, being unable to hop on one foot at 3 is not necessarily a sign of developmental delay. D. Catch a ball reliably: Catching a ball reliably is a more advanced skill that is typically developed around 4 to 5 years. While some 3-year-olds may begin attempting to catch a ball, it is not expected that they can do it reliably at this age.

questions.text: Bidextrous grasp develops at what age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5 months. The bidextrous grasp, also known as the two-handed grasp or bilateral coordination, typically develops around 5 months of age. At this stage, babies start using both hands together in a coordinated manner, such as bringing objects to their mouth or holding and manipulating toys using both hands. This marks a significant milestone in fine motor development. Incorrect responses: A. 3 months: At 3 months, babies are still primarily using their hands reflexively and may not yet be able to grasp objects with both hands. Their hand movements are often less coordinated at this age, and they may be starting to reach and bat at objects. C. 7 months: By 7 months, babies generally develop more refined motor skills, including a raking grasp or the ability to pick up objects with their hands. However, the bidextrous grasp typically occurs earlier, around 5 months, rather than 7 months. D. 9 months: By 9 months, babies are generally becoming more proficient in grasping objects with a pincer grasp (using the thumb and forefinger), which is a more advanced form of grasp. The bidextrous grasp is typically achieved earlier than this stage.

questions.text: Milk is deficient in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iron and vitamin C. Milk is a great source of several nutrients like calcium, protein, vitamin D, and phosphorus, but it is deficient in iron and vitamin C. Milk contains only trace amounts of iron, which makes it insufficient as a sole source of iron for infants or children. Additionally, milk lacks vitamin C, which is essential for iron absorption and overall immune health. Therefore, iron and vitamin C are typically obtained from other foods, as milk alone cannot provide adequate amounts of these nutrients. Incorrect responses: B. Iron and vitamin A: While milk is low in iron, it is actually a good source of vitamin A (especially if fortified). Vitamin A in milk is important for vision and immune function, so this option is incorrect. C. Phosphorus and vitamin C: Milk contains phosphorus in significant amounts, which is essential for bone health and metabolism. However, it lacks vitamin C, so this option is also incorrect. D. Phosphorus and vitamin A: Milk is rich in phosphorus and vitamin A, so this option is not correct. It is not deficient in either of these nutrients.

questions.text: Breastmilk is deficient in all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitamin C Breast milk is a rich source of many essential nutrients, but it does have certain deficiencies in specific vitamins. Of the options provided, vitamin C is not deficient in breast milk. In fact, breast milk contains vitamin C, which is crucial for the baby’s immune function and iron absorption. Incorrect responses: A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Breast milk is low in vitamin B1 (thiamine). While it does provide some amount, infants may require additional thiamine from other sources or supplementation, particularly in cases where the mother is deficient in vitamin B1. C. Vitamin D: Breast milk is deficient in vitamin D. Although breast milk contains some vitamin D, it typically does not provide enough to meet an infant’s needs. This is why vitamin D supplementation is recommended for exclusively breastfed infants. D. Vitamin K: Breast milk is also low in vitamin K, which is essential for blood clotting. This is one of the reasons why newborns are given a vitamin K injection shortly after birth to prevent hemorrhagic disease.

questions.text: Breast milk can be stored in a refrigerator upto?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 24 hours. Breast milk can be safely stored in a refrigerator at a temperature of 4°C (39°F) for up to 24 hours. This helps maintain the freshness and nutritional quality of the milk while also minimizing bacterial growth. After 24 hours, the milk should be discarded to ensure the baby’s safety. It's important to note that breast milk should not be refrozen once thawed. Incorrect responses: A. 4 hours: While 4 hours is a safe time for storing freshly expressed breast milk at room temperature, it is not the recommended duration for refrigerated storage. Refrigerated breast milk can be stored longer—up to 24 hours. B. 8 hours: 8 hours is also shorter than the recommended 24 hours for refrigerated breast milk storage. While this is within a safe range, it is not the maximum recommended time. C. 12 hours: 12 hours is acceptable for storing breast milk in the refrigerator, but again

questions.text: Compared with cow’s milk, mother’s milk has more?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lactose Mother's milk contains more lactose than cow's milk. Lactose is the primary carbohydrate in human breast milk, and it plays a crucial role in providing energy for the infant’s growth and development. Human breast milk has a higher concentration of lactose (approximately 7%) compared to cow's milk, which makes it more suitable for infants' nutritional needs in their early stages of life. Incorrect responses: B. Vitamin D: Cow's milk is typically fortified with vitamin D, whereas mother’s milk contains very little vitamin D. As a result, breastfed infants are often advised to take a vitamin D supplement to ensure they are getting enough of this essential nutrient. C. Proteins: Cow's milk contains more protein than human breast milk. While both types of milk contain proteins necessary for growth, the protein content in cow's milk is higher, which is why it is not recommended as a sole source of nutrition for infants under 1 year. D. Fats: While mother's milk contains healthy fats necessary for infant development, especially for brain growth, cow's milk typically has more saturated fats. Breast milk has a more balanced composition of fats, including essential fatty acids, but it is not significantly higher in total fat content compared to cow's milk.

questions.text: Para amino benzoic acid present in breast milk protects against infection from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PABA in breast milk protects against malarial infection.

questions.text: The average whey: casein ratio in breast milk is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 60:40 The average whey to casein ratio in human breast milk is approximately 60:40. This means that 60% of the protein content in breast milk is whey protein, and 40% is casein protein. This ratio is ideal for the infant, as whey proteins are easily digested and provide rapid absorption of nutrients, while casein forms curds in the stomach, which helps slow down digestion and ensures a steady release of amino acids. Incorrect responses: B. 80:20: This ratio is incorrect because breast milk has more casein in comparison to whey. While 80:20 is the ratio found in cow's milk, it does not reflect the composition of human breast milk, where whey predominates. C. 20:80: This is the opposite of the correct ratio. This would mean breast milk would have far more casein than whey, which is not the case for human milk. It is also the inverse of cow’s milk. D. 40:60: This is the reverse of the correct whey to casein ratio in breast milk. The correct ratio is 60:40, not 40:60.

questions.text: The Calcium: Phosphorous ratio in breast milk is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2:1 The calcium to phosphorus ratio in breast milk is approximately 2:1. This ratio is crucial for the optimal development of the infant's bones and teeth. The calcium and phosphorus in breast milk are in a bioavailable form, which means they can be easily absorbed and utilized by the infant’s body for healthy bone development. The 2:1 ratio supports the optimal calcium absorption while promoting bone mineralization in the growing child. Incorrect responses: A. 1:2: This ratio suggests a higher amount of phosphorus compared to calcium, which is not the case in breast milk. The calcium content in breast milk is higher than phosphorus, so this option is incorrect. C. 1:1: This ratio indicates an equal amount of calcium and phosphorus, which is also not the composition found in breast milk. The correct ratio is 2:1, with more calcium than phosphorus. D. 3:1: This ratio would indicate an even higher calcium content than phosphorus, which is not typical for human breast milk. The correct ratio is closer to 2:1, with a slightly higher amount of calcium than phosphorus.

questions.text: Which among the following is a contraindication to breastfeeding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Active untreated TB. Active untreated tuberculosis (TB) is a contraindication to breastfeeding because the infection can be transmitted to the infant through close contact, including through the breast milk if the mother is not receiving treatment. Active TB, especially if untreated, can lead to serious complications for both the mother and the child, including the potential transmission of the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Incorrect responses: A. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is typically not transmitted through breast milk. The infection is usually spread through fecal-oral routes, so breastfeeding is safe for mothers with Hepatitis A, as long as proper hygiene practices are followed. B. Hepatitis B: While Hepatitis B can be transmitted through blood and bodily fluids, breastfeeding is generally safe for mothers who are infected with Hepatitis B. The virus is not transmitted via breast milk in significant amounts, and the benefits of breastfeeding outweigh the risk. In cases where the mother is Hepatitis B positive, infants should receive the Hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG (Hepatitis B immune globulin) soon after birth. C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted through breast milk, especially in mothers who have had a recent infection. However, breastfeeding is not absolutely contraindicated in CMV infection. If the mother is symptomatic or has a primary CMV infection, the risk of transmission to the infant may be higher, but the benefits of breastfeeding generally outweigh the risks. In some cases, it's recommended to temporarily withhold breastfeeding until the mother is no longer shedding the virus.

questions.text: Toad skin is produced due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vitamin A. Toad skin is a condition characterized by rough, dry, and scaly skin, and it is often associated with vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy skin, and a deficiency in this vitamin can lead to various skin-related issues, including dryness, hyperkeratosis, and a toad-like appearance. This condition is also known as xerosis and is commonly observed in children with insufficient vitamin A intake. Incorrect responses: B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Vitamin B2 deficiency typically leads to conditions like angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis, but not toad skin. It is essential for energy metabolism and the maintenance of healthy skin and mucous membranes, but its deficiency does not cause rough, dry skin like in vitamin A deficiency. C. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to conditions such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, both of which affect bone health. It is not typically associated with rough or scaly skin like toad skin. D. Biotin: Biotin deficiency can lead to symptoms such as hair loss, dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, but it does not cause the toad-like appearance of the skin, which is more characteristic of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Casal necklace is seen due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pellagra. The Casal necklace is a clinical sign that is characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). Pellagra is often associated with symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, commonly referred to as the "three Ds." The Casal necklace refers to a dark, reddened, and scaly rash that forms in a necklace-like pattern around the neck and sometimes the upper chest. This is a classic sign of pellagra, indicating severe niacin deficiency. Incorrect responses: A. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, not niacin. It is characterized by symptoms such as gingival bleeding, petechiae, and poor wound healing. It does not lead to the development of the Casal necklace. B. Marasmus: Marasmus is a form of malnutrition caused by severe calorie and protein deficiency. While it leads to muscle wasting and growth retardation, it does not cause the characteristic Casal necklace seen in pellagra. D. Kwashiorkor: Kwashiorkor is another form of malnutrition that results from a deficiency of protein in the diet. It is associated with edema, ascites, and skin changes, but it does not cause the Casal necklace, which is specific to pellagra.

questions.text: Daily protein requirement in a 2-year old child is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 13 gm. The daily protein requirement for a 2-year-old child is approximately 13 grams. This amount is necessary to support the child's growth, development, and immune function. Protein is essential for building and repairing tissues, as well as producing enzymes and hormones. At 2 years of age, the child is growing rapidly, and sufficient protein intake is crucial to ensure proper development. Incorrect responses: B. 25 gm: A protein requirement of 25 grams is too high for a 2-year-old child. This amount is typically more appropriate for older children or adults with higher activity levels and greater muscle mass. C. 40 gm: 40 grams of protein is also too high for a 2-year-old. This amount is more in line with the protein needs of an older child or an adolescent. D. 60 gm: 60 grams of protein is excessive for a 2-year-old child. This amount is usually required for adults or individuals with specific health conditions or higher protein demands.

questions.text: In which stage of Vitamin A deficiency, corneal xerosis is seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stage X2. Corneal xerosis is a condition characterized by dryness and thickening of the cornea and is a sign of moderate to severe Vitamin A deficiency. It typically appears in Stage X2 of Vitamin A deficiency. In this stage, there is damage to the surface of the eye, specifically the cornea, leading to dryness and a dull, hazy appearance of the cornea. This condition can lead to further complications like night blindness and, if left untreated, may progress to corneal ulceration and blindness. Incorrect responses: A. Stage X1: In Stage X1 of Vitamin A deficiency, the primary symptoms are usually night blindness and possibly some dryness of the conjunctiva, but corneal xerosis has not yet developed at this stage. This is an earlier, milder stage of deficiency. C. Stage X3A: Stage X3A is a more severe form of Vitamin A deficiency, characterized by the development of keratomalacia, which involves softening of the cornea, often leading to blindness. Corneal xerosis is observed in Stage X2, not in this more advanced stage. D. Stage X3B: This stage of deficiency is similar to Stage X3A, with further progression of corneal damage leading to ulceration and scarring. Corneal xerosis is a less severe form of eye damage, which is seen in Stage X2.

questions.text: Which gene mutation is responsible for acrodermatitis enteropathica?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SLC39A4. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the SLC39A4 gene, which encodes a zinc transporter. This mutation leads to impaired zinc absorption in the intestines, resulting in zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency is the underlying cause of the characteristic symptoms of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which include dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia. The disorder is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Incorrect responses: A. RAS: RAS gene mutations are commonly associated with various types of cancer and some developmental disorders, but they are not related to acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is specifically caused by zinc deficiency due to mutations in the SLC39A4 gene. C. PAX6: PAX6 mutations are associated with aniridia (absence of the iris), as well as other eye malformations. It is not related to the pathophysiology of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which involves zinc metabolism. D. SMARC45: SMARC45 is not related to acrodermatitis enteropathica. It is associated with some neurological conditions, but it does not play a role in the pathogenesis of this skin disorder.

questions.text: Abnormalities in copper metabolism are implicated in the pathogenesis of all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cardiomyopathy. Cardiomyopathy is not typically caused by abnormalities in copper metabolism, although copper plays an essential role in several enzymatic processes in the body, including those involved in cardiovascular health. Abnormal copper metabolism is primarily implicated in other diseases, such as Indian childhood cirrhosis, Menke's disease, and Wilson disease, but cardiomyopathy is generally not a direct result of copper metabolism abnormalities. Incorrect responses: B. Indian childhood cirrhosis: Indian childhood cirrhosis is a rare, inherited disorder associated with abnormal copper metabolism. It typically leads to liver cirrhosis and is caused by defective copper transport. It is one of the diseases where abnormalities in copper metabolism play a key role. C. Menke's disease: Menke's disease is a copper transport disorder that results from mutations in the ATP7A gene. This disease leads to defective copper absorption and transport, causing neurological and connective tissue issues. It is directly related to abnormalities in copper metabolism. D. Wilson disease: Wilson disease is another copper metabolism disorder, specifically a genetic condition that causes copper accumulation in various organs, particularly the liver and brain. It leads to liver disease, neurological symptoms, and psychiatric issues due to abnormal copper handling in the body.

questions.text: Inheritance of vitamin D dependent rickets type I?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Autosomal recessive. Vitamin D-dependent rickets type I (VDDR-I) is an inherited disorder that is caused by mutations in the CYP27B1 gene, which encodes the enzyme 1-alpha-hydroxylase. This enzyme is responsible for converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Without the active form of vitamin D, calcium and phosphate metabolism is disrupted, leading to rickets (softening of the bones due to poor mineralization). VDDR-I is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that both copies of the gene (one from each parent) must be mutated for the disease to manifest. Incorrect responses: A. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance means that only one copy of the gene needs to be mutated for the disease to occur. Vitamin D-dependent rickets type I does not follow this pattern, as it requires two copies of the mutated gene to cause the disorder. C. X-linked dominant: X-linked dominant inheritance refers to diseases caused by mutations in genes located on the X chromosome. VDDR-I is not X-linked but rather inherited through autosomal recessive inheritance. D. X-linked recessive: X-linked recessive inheritance involves mutations in genes on the X chromosome that affect males more severely than females. VDDR-I is not X-linked, so this option does not apply.

questions.text: Alopecia is associated with which variety of rickets?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2. Explanation: Alopecia (hair loss) is a characteristic feature of Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2 (VDDR-II), which is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the VDR (Vitamin D receptor) gene. This mutation leads to a defective receptor for the active form of vitamin D, impairing its ability to regulate calcium and phosphate metabolism, resulting in rickets. Alopecia is one of the distinctive features of VDDR-II, along with other symptoms like rickets (bone deformities) and hypocalcemia (low calcium levels). Incorrect responses: A. X-linked dominant rickets: Alopecia is not typically associated with X-linked dominant rickets. This form of rickets is caused by mutations in the PHEX gene and typically results in bone deformities and hypophosphatemia (low phosphate levels), but not alopecia. C. Nutritional rickets: Nutritional rickets, caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, does not generally lead to alopecia. The primary symptoms of nutritional rickets include bone deformities (such as bowed legs) and growth retardation due to a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate in the diet. Alopecia is not a typical feature. D. All of the above: Since alopecia is specifically associated with Vitamin D-dependent rickets type 2 (and not the other forms of rickets mentioned), D. All of the above is incorrect.

questions.text: Best assessment of Vitamin C status in an infant is done by measuring levels of Vitamin C in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Buffy coat. Explanation: The best assessment of Vitamin C status in an infant is done by measuring levels of Vitamin C in the buffy coat. The buffy coat is a thin layer of white blood cells and platelets that separates from plasma when blood is centrifuged. Vitamin C is actively involved in immune function, and white blood cells are rich in Vitamin C. Therefore, measuring Vitamin C levels in the buffy coat can provide a more accurate reflection of the body's vitamin C status, particularly in infants where plasma levels may not always fully reflect vitamin status. Incorrect responses: A. Plasma: Measuring Vitamin C levels in plasma can be useful, but it is less sensitive than measuring levels in the buffy coat. Plasma levels may not always correlate as well with tissue stores or cellular Vitamin C status, particularly in cases of deficiency. B. Urine: Urine levels of Vitamin C can be affected by renal function and may not reliably reflect overall Vitamin C status. The body excretes excess Vitamin C in the urine, so measuring urinary Vitamin C levels may not be the best way to assess deficiency, especially in infants. D. Adrenal cortex: The adrenal cortex is not a primary site for Vitamin C storage or utilization. While Vitamin C does play a role in adrenal gland function, measuring Vitamin C levels in the adrenal cortex is not typically used for assessing vitamin C status in infants.
